channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: #168 - Some Berry Good News For Windows Users
item.description: This week we have something that is bound to make our Windows-using brethren happy: berrybrew, a perlbrew/plenv equivalent for Strawberry Perl, by David Farrell. We also have a few nice grant reports. And, in the everlasting fun department, Sinan's playing with quines lead to dark archaeological discoveries about 'open' and 'autodie'. Enjoy! Oh, and if you are based in Canada, happy Thanksgiving! ~ `/anick
item.dc:subject: list of tags?

item.title: We are Hiring a Senior Perl Software Developer - Grant Street Group
item.description: We are a growing software company using open source software/modern Perl practices to build innovative e-payment, auction, and tax collection web applications. We are looking for talented, motivated professionals committed to flawless work and customer service.

item.title: Hello berrybrew, the Strawberry Perl version manager
item.description: Windows users, prepare to squeal in glee. David Farrell introduces his berrybrew, a Strawberry Perl version manager (think perlbrew/plenv, but for the Windows platform).

item.title: 10 ways of implementing Polymorphism
item.description: Caleb Cushing reviews the -- fittingly -- many ways that can be used to implement polymorphism.

item.title: Travis-CI Helpers for Perl
item.description: Want to harness the full power of Travis-CI for your Perl projects? Graham Knop has a few helper tools that will assist you on your quest for the Continuous Integration Grail.

item.title: Multiple expected values - testing dice
item.description: How can you test a function such as dice() that is expected to return a whole number between 1 and 6? How not to test it?

item.title: Implementing 'is_any' to test multiple expected values
item.description: Refactoring the test script, creating a test function.

item.title: Building Ansible Modules with Perl and Mojolicious
item.description: Ansible is one of those snazzy tools that automate the installation and management of software/configuration/all the things on armies of machines. It's written in Python, but works well with components written in anything else. Marcus Ramberg shows us how his Perl scripts interfaces with it using Mojolicious.

item.title: Elasticsearch Custom Scoring
item.description: Elasticsearch default scoring doesn't quite do it for your special case? Despair not, for Mateu shows us here how to tweak the scoring algorithm in any way we want.

item.title: Why was documentation for open FILEHANDLE removed from perlfunc?
item.description: Mistake, or sinister conspiracy to mask Perl's terrible secrets? Sinan Unur unearthed hidden lore about the 'open' function from Perl's git history.

item.title: A bug in Perl's autodie
item.description: While crafting a Perl quine, Sinan Unur came across a very peculiar corner case bug of autodie.

item.title: The Hacker News API
item.description: Neil Bowers released a Perl interface to the Hacker News API. It's new, it's basic but, and that's the important part, it's there and working; patches will eventually take care of the rest.

item.title: Synchronizing Opera bookmarks with Perl, Org, and git
item.description: A little bit of glue can do wonders to tie systems together. Here, perlancar shows us a script he's using to turn his browser's bookmarks in a git-monitored syncable Org document.

item.title: How does open 0; print <0>; turn every Perl program into a quine?
item.description: In the scientific world "now that's funny..." usually announces a major breakthrough. In the Perl world, as Sinan Unur illustrates, it's typically a harbinger of golfing fun.

item.title: Tony Cook's Grant Extended
item.description: Tony Cook will be able to dedicate 400 more hours on the noble task of maintaining Perl 5, Karen Pauley reports.

item.title: Final TPF Devel::Cover grant report
item.description: Paul Johnson reports on his awesome Devel::Cover work (tl;dr? just go to cpancover.com and stare at the covered beauty of it all).

item.title: 2014.40: Weekly changes in and around Perl 6
item.description: timotimo reviews what happened in the world of Perl6 this week.

item.title: Which Perl modules are loaded in memory?
item.description: Explaining %INC.

item.title: MetaCPAN Task::Kensho
item.description: Screencast about Task::Kensho, the list of recommended modules.

item.title: Perl-related events
item.description: In the following cities: Barcelona (Spain), London (UK), Pittsburgh (PA/USA), Helsinki (Finland), Paris (France)
